  • Apply
Print it!

description.text: I created a raspberry pi controlled drone as part of my science fair project that would eventually compete at the state level in the Texas State Science and Engineering Fair. This bad boy has served me well and I want to share this easy to print and assemble design to you guys in the 3D printed community!

Assembly and considerations

I cadded the whole quadcopter in Inventor from scratch in order to be easily and quickly 3D printed. To assemble the quadcopter, simply lay the angled arms into the main body and then snap on the top plates to sandwich everything together. The top plate, pegs, and spacer pieces are purely optional. I added then in case you wanted to place the battery on top of the quadcopter. For extra strength, I glued everything together with 2 part epoxy. Sanding may be necessary depending on the quality of the printer you are using*

comments.text: I am looking into making a raspberry Pi quadcopter as well for a mechanics course. Can you explain more about where you went to learn about the pi programming and your connection to it?  Did you use wifi/blue tooth?
comments.author: BenderPrints

comments.text: To program the Pi, I used a python library called pyMultiWii, which was created by a GitHub user named alduxvm. The library allowed me to establish a serial connection between the Pi and the Naze32 flight controller (FC) I used to control the power going to each of the 4 brushless DC motors. More specifically, the pyMultiWii library sent numerical data from the Pi to the 8-channel input of the Naze32 FC (via a USB cable). Aside from establishing the serial connection between the two devices, I had to create my own code to make the quadcopter fly by itself. Essentially, I had a sequence of instructions that the Pi would follow to follow a particular flight path. To manually control the quadcopter, I connected my laptop to the Pi using Putty (SSH wifi protocol). This connection would allow me to remote start the quadcopter and monitor sensor data sent by the FC. Alduxvm has an excellent youtube channel that can help you better understand the control flow I used.

title: Timelapse Harness US Mic Stand Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
nigeljohnson73 made a great timelapse harness, but it only worked with the Raspberry Pi Camera Module version 1, so I made a version that worked with the RPi Camera Module v2.1

Then, I decided that I wanted to try and secure his timelapse harness to something. I have a few mic stands kicking around, and they have a standard US head (5/8"-27). So I worked this adapter up in Fusion 360, which has (on the short side) the mic stand threads, and on the long-side (to accommodate the bolts), the timelapse harness threads. After much trial and error, I figured out that the timelapse harness threads are a standard M16x2.0 metric.

I almost made a support piece/hook ("hook_front_v2.stl") which connects the harness to the FlashForge Creator Pro (2016 edition), but when I tried to connect it using the harness, a piece, and gaffers tape, it jiggled around too much. So having the camera external to the unit is preferable for now. I may make the support piece/hook later but, probably not an itch I need to scratch at the moment.

I think the next thing I'm going to create an adapter for is for a standard tripod/camera head.

I think it may now be time to print a Baby Groot!

description.text:
A foot mount for the Anycubic line of Delta Printers.

It would probably fit other Deltas, since it's made to fit an equilateral corner, but the outside radius is a fit for the geometry of an Anycubic frame.

Significantly cuts down on resonant noise of the printer through its resting surface.

Doesn't increase the footprint of the printer base.

Printer:

Anycubic Linear Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1-.3

Infill:

50-100% cubic

Notes:

Could easily be printed with a raft or brim.
No supports necessary. Select your infill preference, but since your printer will be resting on these consider a stout infill with at least 1mm wall thickness.

Print on the mounting face; legs pointing in the +z direction.

I printed this at 65% infill with 1.6mm walls and I could stand my entire body weight on just one of these legs (I'm 165lbs).

Designed in Solidworks.

I always wanted a car that would print with the wheels in place and then move. I was finally pushed into action by one of my current 6th graders. I shared my idea with her, guided her in a few areas and she created an epic car. After she was successful, I had to wrap up my own. This is the finished product.

The key to the design is creating with "squished" spheres. I could create a small area that was attached to the bed and the shape of the sphere allowed me to grow the creation and still get nice results.

Next step is to add a fin. =)

If you would like to build along, I have posted instructions on YouTube. https://youtu.be/lZF3fQv3ZjA There is a lot of room for modification and the end results are pretty sweet.

I have also added a video showing Kamryn's creation. https://youtu.be/AGZ91don2iA

remixed_from.title: kinect ergonomic handle - one file - no support

description.text:
When I saw tokagehideto's handle grip for the Kinect I thought it was almost perfect. I have been wanting to use the Kinect V1 both handheld and on a tripod so I just added the piece in the front. The added length doesn't seem to get into the way when the scanner is level to the base. Adding the nut to mount it to the tripod is a little tricky, I didn't want it to be visiable from the top so you have to add the 1/4 nut during the printing process. The nut location starts to close at 9.7mm from the print bed so you have to watch closely. The nut I used was about 5.6mm high and 10.96mm from flat edge to flat edge.

Thanks tokagehideto for the original grip.

I'm not very good with 3D CAD yet so the part might be seperate from the handle. If the part is seperate, in Cura or whatever print software you use,just put the part into the handle a little ways and it will print as one piece.

title: Toggles - iPad Goggles for VR and Stereoscopics

description.text:
Toggles are a 3D printed sleeve that goes over the top of your iPad Mini (4th generation). Combined with a viewer app, the Toggles allow you to split for screen into the top half for stereoscopic images, movies or VR. The bottom part of the screen can then be used for navigation, buttons, overhead views.

One of the biggest problems we have with Google Cardboard or other mobile VR viewers is that you are immediately inconvenienced with having an object strapped to your head and the ineffective ways to navigate within the 3D world you are peeking into. The Toggles keep things more casual and let you quickly click through locations.

Toggles FUN

https://skfb.ly/67A9N

Toggles

https://skfb.ly/67A9T

INSTRUCTIONS

Print 1 x of either the toggles.stl or the toggles-fun.stl (this has cartoon eyes and holes for easy access to the back).

Print 2 x ring_top.stl files. These are the snap on tops that keep the lenses secure.

If you want to have the cartoon eyes effect, print 2 x eyeball.stl and snap them into the back side holes. Print with different colored filament or paint for a desired effect.

Currently this Toggle supports the 25mm diameter 45mm focal length lenses that are common to Google Cardboard. About $7 usually on Amazon.

https://www.amazon.com/Blisstime-Bi-convex-Biconvex-Diameter-Cardboard/dp/B00WJGTGB2

Assemble and then place your iPad in the Toggles from the bottom.

VIEWER SOFTWARE

We've put together an initial movie viewer in Github that can be downloaded and compiled. It can be found here:

https://github.com/Exhilent/TOGGLESVR

This viewer is based on nodejs, Ionic, Cordova and will compile as a hybrid iOS app in Xcode.

CONTRIBUTE TO MAKE IT BETTER

In the future, we are hoping that many contributors help by delivering open source software that can be used with these Toggles. Also we have plans for different bigger lenses and experimenting more with the aesthetics of the Toggles.

This is version one and we plan to be improving these over time. If you'd like to participate, please send us a note. We'd like to get a Unity driven application delivered to the community soon.

We will be documenting and expanding on the comments for these Toggles on our company site located here:

https://www.exhilent.com/togglesvr

We believe these tablet goggles to have a powerful educational use and look forward to solutions that are built for them. Corporate folks who want to really stand out at an event. Get in touch.

[email protected]

Here are some hearts for Valentine's day designed to be easy and quick to print. They were constructed from the number 6 plane curve at mathworld. http://mathworld.wolfram.com/HeartCurve.html Five objects are available - pin.stl - a heart with a fitting for a safety pin
box.stl - a small box
lid.stl - a lid for the box
pendant_mark_01.stl - a single sided pendant
pendant_mark_02.stl - a double sided pendant OpenSCAD code is included.

The lid and pendant_mark_02.stl need to be printed with support.  The pin can be printed directly on the build surface but has a more finished back if support is used.  
Pendant_mark_01 and the box can be printed directly on the build platform.  
A safety pin can be installed on the pin's back and secured with a small piece of 1.8 mm printing plastic.  
Glueing two single sided pendants together makes a nicely finished version of the double sided pendant.

title: RPI3 2600 (raspberry pi 3 enclosure)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT: made some adjustments to the base model for a better fit...

I always planned on modeling a Atari2600 case for a pi,... I was about to start from scratch, when I did a search here on thingiverse... there were two models, one from a few years ago, and a new one that the bottom half was for the RPI3
I could have just used those models, but I wanted a bit more detail, and access to the SD card, (neither had that)..... so I remodeled the meshes back into solids, and made all the necessary resizing and adjustments... ....I also wanted more detail added to the faceplate, and wanted it easier to print, so I made it separate from the top.... I also wanted the top hollowed out for switches, LED's or whatever... one last detail I added was the RPI3 (atari logo) ..... anyway, I was hoping I didn't have to reinvent the wheel, but in the end I "kinda" did....

"THIS IS FOR NON-COMMERCIAL USE, THAT MEANS NO F**KEN EBAY, ETSY, FLEA MARKETS OR WHEREVER ELSE.... AGAIN THIS IS NOT TO BE SOLD IN ANY WAY SHAPE OR FORM".... YOU KNOW WHO YOU ARE YOU SCUMBAGS!!!

title: Strix AWK210 & RMRC Hellbender Camera Lens Adapter

description.text: If you own a RMRC AWK210 or Hellbender multi-rotor then you've noticed the FPV camera doesn't fit too well in the camera mounts, unless you are using the Strix Ochi camera. This ring will go around the camera lens, and when you tighten the screw to hold it in place the camera wont tilt at an angle and will protect the lens threads from being bent. I glue the ring on the lens.

description.text: This model provides a 2x2 inch nest of eggs. I have also provided two broken separate egg shells that can be printed and placed freely on the nest. The egg shells need supports, while the scenic top cap does not. I have also provided a nest with the openlock system base. The nest can also be placed on a true tile base by increasing its size by 25%. It is recommend if you do this that the bottom be trimmed one and a half millimeters so as not to have too high of a tile. The Wylock or true tile base can be obtained from this website. http://www.heroshoard.com/true-tiles for free.

description.text:
I bought a small size power supply for my Hypercube (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752766) and I had to create a new bracket since the one posted by Tech2C didn't fit my PS.

Power supply I got: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/360W-12V-30A-Small-Volume-Single-Output-Switching-power-supply-Driver-For-LED-Light-Strip-Display/32787393303.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.WANm9H

30%

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O-9RETaBMVw&t=1s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2ddw3MQl9g
The hand files are part of a larger project which has taken around two years. The project is an entirely 3D printed humanoid robot similar to the inmoov project but with many major differences in design. It features an improved gripping design and an opposable thumb. This is created to be incredibly inexpensive, simple to make, and reliable, I have put the arm through some rigorous stress testing, and it's able to run for hours on end without a hitch. I will publish the rest of the arm designs in the near future. My current goal is to gain funding through sponsorship or donations to continue my research.
Assembly of the arm is very simple and forthright but I will post a video on how to assemble the arm very soon (the order in which you assemble is crucial).

Materials needed for the arm:
-Flexible Nylon Paracord: http://www.paracordplanet.com/black-1-8-shock-cord/?gclid=CjwKEAjwoPG8BRCSi5uu6d6N5WcSJABHzD8F0L0fHDhT_dqwNNAAP0UubP1OmgCBMNTkp_OyXJ0xuBoC05Tw_wcB
-Standard sized servos x5 (these are the servos I used but any standard sized servo will work well): https://www.banggood.com/Towerpro-MG958-55g-20KG-High-Torque-Digital-Metal-Gear-Servo-p-978254.html?rmmds=search
-Micro servo: https://www.amazon.com/TowerPro-MG90S-Geared-Helicopter-Trex450/dp/B01F7MRR38/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1493004060&sr=8-7&keywords=micro+servo+metal+gear
-Fishing line between .5mm and .8mm you can get this anywhere

Tools needed for assembly:
-Super Glue
-Plyers
-Screwdriver
-Exacto Knife or Scissors

CODING:

My partner in this project who deals with all the programming just recently published all the files on how to control the arm with the LEAP on his gifthub page-----
https://github.com/tt-anderson

This code, in particular, is what took us many months to perfect so I sincerely hope you guys enjoy using it!

title: 2017 Toyota Tacoma bed rail tie down

description.text:
This is a tie-down insert for a 2017 Toyota Tacoma bed rail. It uses a 1/4 inch threaded eye-hook and a 1 1/2 inch washer. the thing includes a sleeve for the washer so it does not scratch the rail. Thing dimensions are in mm.

To install it, screw one nut all the way onto the eye hook, install the washer, install the washer sleelve. put the other nut into the nut-shaped recess in the block and barely screw in the eye-hook until it just catches the nut in the block. Remove the end-plug on the tacoma bed rail and slide the block tinto the rail. place it where you want it on the rail and tighten the eye-hook until the block no longer slides. Replace the end-plug on the rail and you are done. Note that if you want to use an eye-hook that is longer, you can simply adjust the first nut to hold the washer further down the threads. Enjoy!

comments.text: Awesome.  I'm pretty sure the rail hasn't changed from what it was on mine for the 2013 model, so I'll be printing several of these this week.

title: Omnipod Pod Cover - Cutout Diamonds
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a cover for the Omnipod Insulin Pump pods. My wife is a type 1 diabetic who uses the omnipod, and I designed these covers for her as a Christmas gift. From her experience using the covers, they add a negligible amount of weight, they don't really add much to the thickness, and they don't fall off. When you change the pod, they are easy to remove to use on the next one. print_settings.Notes:: I printed mine with 100% infill since where this connects to the frame the part will be squeeze pretty solidly by the bolts.  Since I don't want the part to warp and bend there I printed it full.  You can use support for the bracket if you want since there is a challenging bridge in it.

description.text:
This bracket is the same idea as the one by donnyb99 except for the CR-10 S4. I updated the bracket and end cap. I did not design the puller and knob, these are the same ones as in his design but I added them here for convenience.

There are two brackets. One is the same length as the CR-10 bracket and the other is 10mm longer. I made the longer one in case the belt ever gets that loose. Unless this is your situation just use the normal length bracket.

You will need one M5x30 bolt and M5 nut (M5x40 bolt if you are using the long bracket). This design is a bit beefier than the original for the CR-10 since this part is connected to the frame differently.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100

Notes:

I printed mine with 100% infill since where this connects to the frame the part will be squeeze pretty solidly by the bolts. Since I don't want the part to warp and bend there I printed it full. You can use support for the bracket if you want since there is a challenging bridge in it.

In order to assemble this, you have to remove the existing 3D printed idler and keep the four bolts and nuts, you will re-use them. Do not undo the two metal L brackets.

Remove the belt from the pulley on the other end of Y-axis so that you have more slack to work with.

Push the M5 bolt all the way into the puller so that the hex head rests inside the cutout for it and the threads protrude out the back of it. You may have to lightly tap the M5 into it's place using a hammer and a screwdriver.

Use the existing M4 bolt to put the lock the idler wheel and belt in place inside the puller. Then put the bracket's onto the two metal L brackets and secure it with the four bolts and nuts that you kept when removing the original part.

Push the M5 nut into the slot made for it in idig3d's knob.

Put the belt back onto the pulley at the Y-axis motor.

Lastly, slip the endcap onto the back of the bracket and screw the knob into the M5 bolt.

description.text:
I've printed a few part fan's for the E3D-V6 so far, but this is the first that looks worthy and will stand the test of time! Strong where it needs to be, and the clip holds great.

I just had a problem with the angle of the blower fan (and the removal of the screw tab) on the original, and hate having to use hot glue on a project, especially so close to hot parts.

So I threw it in tinkercad and made the changes I felt were needed.

Ended up really loving how well it fit and turned out, and will get some photo's of it mounted once I've had some sleep :)

Enjoy!

Edit 04-25-17 - Finally mounted and have used it for a few prints, works and fit's everything great! Photos added.

print_settings.Notes:: Because of the hooks, the gears must be printed with supports.

description.text:
This is my first attempt at a geared rope maker.

Notes:

  • The screws are pretty weak, so you may be better off with nylon ones.
  • At 0.25 layer height, the screws should not need post-processing, but the threaded holes will.
  • For best results you either need a M6x1 tap, or a metal M6x1 screw with a groove cut in it to clean up the inside threads.

Updates:

  • Only the 3 screws that hold the frame together are needed, v2 has the extra holes and threads removed.
  • I redid the hooks to hopefully make them print better
  • I make the screws go all the way through for added strength. (Even better would be to use nylon or metal M6x1x15 screws.)
  • Added a new "hook gear" that you just tie the string/thread to. This version does not require supports.

title: Treble Clef Hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hang your bird feeder with this musical hook or add bling to your backpack. It's a quick print so you could print a bunch and pass them out as party favours.

My motivation for this design was to replace the other lovely treble clef hooks that held up my bird feeder. They broke when a huge squirrel attacked the feeder and it fell to the ground. Poor bird feeder. I'll have to reprint that, too, or patch it up with filament.

This is a beefier hook with a shorter engagement arm so it shouldn't snap off as easily. Hope you like it.

title: 4 color American Flag on a 1 color printer

description.text:
this is a learning sample of how to print multi colors on a single color printer
i have chosen the American Flag as most would appreciate this as far as our brother and sisters in other country's just use it as a example

the stars are still not very recognizable in the size it is but you can make it larger and that will increase the detail of the stars

first thing is you must turn off the auto centering of your slicer

i am using xyzware as my slicer and the setting to check is in the settings then the editor tab then uncheck import objects with auto position

i don't know where s3d or the other slicer settings are you will have to find it in your slicer

the trick is a old printing press process that news papers and magazines use is markers around the perimeter of the print one for each color printed with 3d printing you do not nead a different marker for each color but you must use the same markers with all the color layers

i have included the project files in a zip file so you can experiment and understand how i mad this flag

i used inkskape and 123d to make the stars and blue background into a stl from a image then the main program i used is xyzmaker

xyzmaker has stars but i wanted a exact copy of a real flag for the star pattern
i did not recreate the stars i used a image of a flag to transfer the blue and white stars

This iPhone 6S dock is the first relatively complex item I've designed from scratch. I made this for wife's iPhone 6S with the Incipio case and Amazon Basics iPhone charging cable. The charging cable typically doesn't want to be bent pointed up and such a sharp angle, which can be alleviated by feeding additional cable and coiling it around the hook on the back.

Drew inspiration from other iPhone 6S docks that I liked, but wouldn't fit the Incipio case. Also disliked that other docks required so much filament and support structures. So I hollowed the base plate, cropped the sides of the dock, and used triangle-shaped speaker holes to reduce print-time and save material.

description.text:
My take on a fidget spinner mash-up with a fan. I wanted something that would also be of potential functionality and value. While not as effective as a high RPM electric fan it's just as good as most personal hand fans.

When using the fan one will find the airflow is cone shaped and spreads out at a 45-60 degree angle from the fan. Rotating it as it spins also helps with feeling the air moving as you can experience the slight push and pull as it passes.

Video: https://youtu.be/J5-Jdm_CLOE

I designed this to be held in the right hand and spun with the left. It was just comfortable for me that way and was how I noticed my kids holding fans. Since fans only work in one direction you'll need to use the mirror along axis feature (x or y), available in most slicing engines, to use it in the left hand.

20%

Notes:

To get the fan blades nice a high resolution is required. Make sure to tune your supports as they will be difficult to remove without breaking the blades if they stick.

1/4-20 Hex weights

I opted to use 1/4-20 nuts as weights. I've uploaded the CAD file if one should wish to alter the type. They should be a nice fit but occasionally, due to inconsistent printing and/or surface finishing of the nuts by the manufacturer, they can be too big or small.

For the too small I recommend a few drops of super glue and using the Hex caps to seal the nuts in.

For the too large either heat the nut in some hot to boiling water (80-100 C) and press it in (works well for PLA), file away some of the plastic, or press in and hope it doesn't crack the frame.

Design

Designed in Solidworks with 5 iterations. First I attempted to optimize for 3D printing on a single material/nozzle machine; the result of which produced almost no displacement of air.

After that I worked to improve airflow.

title: Heavy duty servo ball valve 1/4" NPT

description.text:
This is an improvement of my previous design : Direct drive servo ball valve (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2131538).
I use it to control the flow of steam out of my DIY boiler, it acts like a proportional valve, tested with Steam at 105°C (221°F).
This design is much cheaper than what you can find on the shelf, but also efficient : full opening takes less than one second.
You will need to drill a 3mm hole on the lever of the ball valve at 40mm from the centre of the ball valve and add a M3 threaded rod bended to have 63mm from the two holes.
The program used on the Uno is "Knob" from the servo library.
BOM :

  • 2x "jumper.stl"
  • 1x "servo_holder.stl"
  • 1x NPT 1/4" ball valve
  • 1x MG996R servo (https://www.banggood.com/TowerPro-MG996R-Digital-Metal-Gear-Servo-For-RC-Model-p-78320.html?p=3A07002553965201509W)
  • 1x metal arm for MG996R servo (https://www.banggood.com/25T-Metal-Servo-Arm-For-RC-Futuba-Towerpro-Servo-MG995R-MG996R-MG945-p-80611.html?p=3A07002553965201509W)
  • M3 threaded rod (https://www.banggood.com/500mm-M3-to-M12-Stainless-Steel-Threaded-Rod-Screw-Rod-p-1028865.html?p=3A07002553965201509W)
  • 8x M3x40mm Screws (https://www.banggood.com/10pcs-M3-Thread-Hexagon-Screw-Bolt-Nut-304-SUS-Socket-Screw-p-977985.html?p=3A07002553965201509W)

My mixture of the new Supergirl with some of the original movie Supergirl.
If printed with PLA only,you get a semi poseable figure. (hips won't move with solid skirt)
For best results the skirt and cape should be printed with flexible filament (if possible)
Print components, remove supports and sand carefully. (top of hip sockets may need extra sanding for clearance)
Assemble waist and thighs first, place skirt over waist/thigh components, insert shoulder joints into back part of torso then assemble torso pieces over waist pin.
For leg assembly, use 1.75mm ABS filament as pins, hot knife ends smoothly into place.
For arm assembly, use pins provided and hot knife the ends smoothly into place.
Assemble both halves of head.
Cape should be placed on doll before head.
Special note: the cape can be difficult to print (only 1mm thick) you may want to make a simple material cape, instead.
(fixed ripple effect can be achieved by positioning material cape then spraying with clear spraypaint, wait to fully dry, cape should remain in desired position, then attach to doll.)
The skirt and cape do not need to be glued in place.
I added a pair of fists in case any one prefers them. (they will probably print easier than the open palmed ones)

title: Collection of 45mm x 45mm MiniTec T-slot extrusion parts

description.text: Parts to attach a stylus and a trim router to the end of MiniTec 45x45 extrusion

I needed to mount a stylus and a router motor onto two arms made from MiniTec 45x45 T-slot extrusion. I printed these in PLA but ABS would work also. I used 0.5mm nozzle and 0.5 mm layer height with high infill to keep them rigid. Clean out the holes and tap the 45x45  mount where appropriate. It slides cleanly onto the MiniTec extrusion after I clean away the stringy bits. The hole in the middle of the circular plates allows for a 8mm bolt to hold the whole thing tightly. The holes around the perimeter of the circular plates allows you to index your tool and stylus at 0, 30, 45, 60 and 90 degrees.

description.text:
On my velux roof window the caps got brittle after 17 years.

I made the part with openscad and tried to make it parametrizable as good as possible.
Have to print two of them and the lower hole was half millimeter larger than top - added a 102% resize to the original file, that worked for me.

Pic3 shows the old part. Pic1 looks much better for me ;-)

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

15% honey

Notes:

I set supports to 1mm in Simplify3D so no supports occurred on the inside.

This is a Receiver antenna holder for the Falcon 250 pro. It secures both coaxial antenna leads at 90 degrees apart, keeps them away from the props and keeps them away from the FPV transmit antenna, so the RC range is less compromised by interference from the FPV transmitter.
It's designed for 3mm frame holes, 34mm apart and nicely fits behind the camera platform and in front of the battery.
You will need to lift off the top panel to turn the receiver around and to route the antenna leads. Don't crimp the leads between surfaces and don't bend them too tightly.

While you're removing the panels, take the time to put some insulating tape between the bottom of all side panels and the base plate. The PCB is badly designed and after time and with vibration the carbon fibre panels rub through the insulation on the PCB and short circuit the tracks. These just happen to be B+ and B-, which causes erratic flying, excessive current and bits of carbon fibre catching fire. Invest the time, you will thank yourself.

Print and enjoy.

title: 5W HF PA enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an enclosure for a 5W HF amplifier which I bought as a kit from QRP labs (http://www.qrp-labs.com/pa.html). Normally this PA is used together with some other electronics inside a metal box. But as I run this PA separately and using a variety of sources and experimental equipment I had to come up with a stand-alone solution.

This enclosure offers physical protection but is not intended for unsupervised outdoor usage as it obviously is not watertight. There are holes for the connectors and the heatsink and mounting the soldered PCB inside is quite straightforward. As the efficiency of the heatsink is reduced by the enclosure (compared to the PCB without any box around) you probably should not go for max power without carefully monitoring the temperature at the beginning.

In addition to the kit and the printed enclosure you will only need four self-tapping screws 3x6 mm to tighten the PCB to the bottom and another four screws 3x9 mm to connect the top of the enclosure to the bottom.

This is a 2-part sandal for kids that can be printed on a Cupcake.

This is a very simple & easy sandal that was designed to fit a ~5 year old (ie, ~kids size 12). Because at the time I only had access to Cupcake, it is designed in two parts that are joined together using acetone. Print the top and bottom halves, and smooth the joint edges with a small flat file until the pieces fit snugly together. Weld them together by putting the pieces together so they are flush, dribbling a small amount of acetone along the joint on both sides, and then squishing the pieces together. Hold firmly for a minute or so and then let dry on something flat (eg. glass or wax paper on a flat board.) To print the other foot, just mirror the parts in ReplicatorG or your printer program. Strap material is 9/16" webbing. A nail is used to hold the strap in at the toe, and the sides and nail are hot-glued down. I also used hot glue in the channels on the bottom to provide a little grip, but other rubbery substances that will stick to your print material could also work. To see detailed instructions and images on how to assemble the pieces as well as instructions on how to design your own custom-fit sandals, see the Instructable here: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-3D-printed-sandals/

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Clone Ramps 1.4 Cover Base + Door

description.text:
Modified Prusa i3 MK2 Cover Base and Door to fit RAMPS 1.4/Arduino.

I have included the modified scad files, as required by the GPL license.
Note that these files may require additional files, which can be found in the Prusa GIT repository.

Also note that the fan grille was taken from another scad file, of which I am unable to identify the original designer. I will remedy this if/when I find out.

If you like my work, please consider a small donation.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Whilst waiting for my genuine Prusa i3 MK2 kit (7 week delivery time), I decided to create a 24V clone of it. I really like the clean installation of the electronics, and so I re-worked the SCAD file to fit the RAMPS/Arduino board. Whilst fitting the board was easy, I had to move some of the cable routes to get the unit to fit comfortably. I also had to ensure that the reset switch was accessible.
.
The door has been modified to take a 40mm fan on the outside, and more ventilation holes have been added. Note that the wire loom will catch on the fan, and you need to extend the X carriage endstop to trigger 15-20mm earlier.

Some ready-made frames come with holes drilled for the ramps board to fit directly, so you may have to drill the original hole locations to fit this box to the frame. Note that the box needs to sit flush with the edges of the frame, or the extruder wire loom with catch on it.

Use with the standard Prusa i3 MK2 hinges to complete...

title: Secret Life of Walter Mitty wallet

description.text: This is a very simple wallet for people who have never made a wallet like me and want to try this. The model is based on the wallet in the movie "The secret life of Walter Mitty". It is a clumsy wallet but fun to make. The cutting is straight forward. I used some leather 26 x 18 cm and 10 x 26cm from eBay that cost me around $15. See my blog http://awesome.tech/making-a-wallet/ for more details. Also engraved the wallet with the text from the movie but up to you whether to use that or not. Have fun making!

title: Printrbot Simple Extruder Fan, Cooling Fan, and LED Ring Mount

description.text:
This is a combination of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220269, and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217224. It combines an extruder fan mount, an LED ring mount, and a new mount for the cooling fan. I added supports and reinforced the back. I may have overdone it with the reinforcement.
Edit: Now includes a mutilated version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231661 to replace the original fan mount.

Print the supported version as is and cut off the supports. Bolt a 40mm 12 volt fan onto the funnel then follow the instructions from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217224/#instructions. I haven't wired mine up yet, so you're on your own for now.

comments.text: I did it again. Butchered a perfectly good Thing™. This time it was http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231661http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... .This replaces the original fan mounting, since it's just in the way now.

title: President Donald J. Trump Bobble Head Remix

description.text:
Every Red Blooded American should had a President Donald J. Trump in their house, or they could be classed as un-American.

If you want to watch how i made this very patriotic model watch my video at https://youtu.be/igHklih-tVs

This is a remix of ShaggyDude version. I hope he does not mind.

I cut the pieces so they could be printed without using any support.

I decided to give The President a Blue suit and Yellow skin color, but this could be changed if you wanted to paint him after printing.

Printer:

Prusa Mendel Iteration 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used a brim on prints to help it stick to the heat-bed.

I also had my printer set to do 3 shells and 10% infill.

After printing I glued the body parts together and also glued the head parts together. I personally did not do the best gluing job possible, but it could be easily fixed if I decided to paint the model.

4 T-Nuts
4 M4 10mm bolts

You will need to print at least 2 LockingNut.stl, but i printed 3, the third locks the SpoolBolt.stl in place.

The threads turn well, but it they're too stiff some WD40 or Bike Grease will help them turn easier. It is a good idea to print the LockingNut.stl and SpoolBolt.stl at 102% though, just to give the thread that extra tiny bit of room.

Depending on your printer layout you may need to mirror FrameMount.stl to avoid having the filament hang over the print bed.

The idea for the opposing cones to hold the filament came from the filastruder.

The bearing that goes into the SpoolBolt.stl may need some super glue depending on your machines accuracy. I had to sand mine down and press fit so your mileage may vary.

Last point, the HolderBolt.stl carries a lot of weight on it's tip, so the more solid you can make that end the better. I gave mine 10 layers of wall thickness after the first one snapped with only 4.

Hope it's useful and happy printing.

I wanted to evaluate my older 3D Printer parts and designed this.

It can be turned to a pen plotter, a drag cutter or a laser engraver.

I've used Makeblock's XYBot firmware and mDraw software.

The following changes should be made in MeOrion.h (In Makeblock's libraries) for the cnc shield:

MePort_Sig mePort[17] =
{
{ NC, NC }, { 5, 2 }, { 6, 3 }, { 10, 9 }, { 8, A2},
{ NC, NC }, { 13, 12 }, { A3, 11 }, { A1, A0 }, { NC, NC},

};

author: ramstutz

title: Integrated Picks Holder for Guitar/Bass (Cort B4)

description.text:
After loosing many many picks, or simply not having one whenever needed, I decicded to create a pick holder that I would always have with me: on the instrument itself :)

This thing is an electronic compartment cover plate for my Cort B4 bass, with an integrated pick holder built-in.

This is inspired by a pick holder by Dunlop I bought several years ago:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s9VZqsx3-CQ

It contains up to 4 to 5 picks.
The picks are stored in a pocket, and pushed up toward the access hole by springs, so that you can store a varying number of picks.

• Cover the back of the plate with aluminium tape

  • Press-fit three 5x15mm compression springs under the pusher tab
  • Assemble the cover plate, pusher with springs and pocket (a small marking indicates the top orientation for each component)
  • Glue the pocket to the cover plate
  • Cover the pocket with aluminium tape
  • Screw the cover plate to your instrument
Designed with Autodesk Fusion360

remixed_from.author: nigeljohnson73
remixed_from.title: B+ Pi Cam Ultimaker 2 timelapse harness

title: Timelapse Harness US Tripod Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
nigeljohnson73 made a great timelapse harness, but it only worked with the Raspberry Pi Camera Module version 1, so I made a version that worked with the RPi Camera Module v2.1

Next, I knew I needed to secure this timelapse harness to something. Mic stands work really well for me, but as a photographer, I realize that more people have tripods than mic stands. Plus, there are a wide variety of tripods - quality, size, stability, price - and there's really only one or two major tripod connections in the US. I chose the most popular one - 1/4-20 UNC - and ran with it. I love the way Fusion 360 handles standard thread sizes, and its library is quite large. So far, it's had every thread size/count I've needed. By the way, the original harness has a standard metric M16x2.0 thread.

Tripods look like this Ʌ and mic stands look like this ꓕ so I'm probably going to go with mic stands in production going forward, because I trip all over tripod legs, whereas mic stands have a much smaller, heavier base. Tripods are more portable, but mic stands are designed to stay where they are put, basically.

Going forward, if you see something I make for the mic stand mount that you'd like converted over to the tripod thread, please let me know in comments or shoot me a private message.

Baby Groot is on the horizon!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Seriously - getting a glass bed, and using PVA glue, and leveling the heck out of the bed, is the best way to print. I don't want to jinx myself and future prints, but the stronger springs that came with my glass bed make it so much easier to keep things level, even after multiple prints and multiple days!

I've been printing with PLA recently, due to the reduced odor, toxicity, and lower temperatures. It seems more forgiving?

Reverse Engineering and Fusion 360

My third remix using reverse engineering, rather than the original STL file. Fewer iterations needed this time to determine the actual thread details, and it was extremely satisfying when my tripod quick-release head connected smoothly with the adapter!

Thanks again to nigeljohnson73 for the exceptional timelapse harness design!

author: BogdanKecman

description.text:
The science department at our school did not like the test tube racks they were using. They found them cumbersome and annoying to use, so we created this new design.

The parts of the test tube rack are printed separately, and they are all detachable. If one of the drying rods snaps, you can either remove it and replace it, or you can print a drying rod sleeve and fit it snugly over the broken stub of the drying rod.

Two test tube racks can be stored compactly by interlocking them within each other. The drying rods on both test tube racks can be inserted simultaneously into the other rack's holding rack (the top piece with six large holes), making two test tube racks take roughly the same amount of space as one.

PARTS:
1 Test Tube Rack Bottom Piece
1 Test Tube Rack Top Piece
6 Test Tube Rack Drying Rods
However many Drying Rod Sleeves are needed

Printer:

Dremel Idea Builder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No
Sanding is sometimes needed if the raft is difficult to remove.

Limitations and obstacles
  • 10cm x 20cm print plate
  • Had to accommodate for risk of drying rods breaking
  • Had to create multiple prototypes, taking suggestions from the science department each time
  • First prototype was too big; had to make it smaller
    • Should the drying rods be printed separately from the bottom piece or printed as a part of it? We began with a detachable drying rod design in our first prototype, decided to try printing the drying rods as part of the bottom piece in our second prototype, and upon realizing this design was prone to breaking, we reverted to a detachable design in our final product.
  • Had to create a test tube rack in which multiple sizes of test tubes could fit
    • Image taken from Solidworks (right: first prototype; left: second prototype)

1) As a class, students discuss and think of products that the science department needs or would like (ex. test tube stirrer, cellular model, etc.)
2) Students divide into groups and each group chooses a product
3) Each group creates an initial design for their product and asks teachers throughout the science department for feedback and suggestions on their design
4) Update the existing design and create a new prototype based on the teachers' suggestions
5) Ask teachers throughout the science department for more suggestions
6) Repeat steps 4 and 5 until a satisfactory final product is created

• 3D printer
  • 3D printer filament
  • 3D design software (such as Solidworks)
